title: Why do musicians still put out albums, since most people are streaming music and not buying physical CDs or records? - Quora

response.answer_text: The trend is definitely away from the traditional, 40-minute, 12-song album, with more artists releasing songs one at a time, or in small batches. The current path to pop stardom seems to be via releasing one song at a time on social media. But recording and releasing songs in batches still makes sense in several ways. First, there is a practical aspect. If you are going to take the time and expense to go into a studio, or otherwise set up a recording environment, and bring together musicians, engineers, etc., you might as well make as much use of it as possible. This is not only economical but also yields a consistent sound. From an artistic perspective, there is still value in presenting more than one song at a time; a group of songs can do more than one at expressing a theme, or displaying a variety of styles and sounds. If people like one song they are going to want to hear more, and releasing a set rather than one or two gives that opportunity. Now you are building a fan base for yourself or your band, rather than just for a song. Finally having an album gives you something to sell at your shows and online; spur-of-the moment sales at a merch table or even an honor box on a bar stage is a non-trivial source of income for many artists. For established artists with a web presence or other distribution channel, physical CD sales, even today, remain far more lucrative than streaming revenue.

Remember to always include a link to any press or fan quotes, quality band photos, a link to your press page with some or all audio from your album. 7.
